factoid: Shinshín said, "Oh yes, I heard it today."
Shinshín entered the Rostóvs’ box.
Natásha looked in the direction her father's eyes were turned.
Natásha saw Julie sitting beside Julie's mother.
Julie had a happy look on her face.
Julie had a string of pearls around her thick red neck.
The string of pearls was covered with powder.
Behind Natásha and Julie, Borís had a handsome smoothly brushed head wearing a smile and leaning over with an ear to Julie’s mouth.
Borís looked at the Rostóvs from under his brows.
Borís said something smiling to his betrothed.
Natásha thought, "They are talking about us, about me and him."
Natásha thought, "And he no doubt is calming her jealousy of me."
Natásha thought, "They needn’t trouble themselves."
Natásha thought, "If only they knew how little I am concerned about any of them."
Anna Mikháylovna sat behind them wearing a green headdress.
Anna Mikháylovna had a happy look of resignation to the will of God on her face.
The Rostóvs’ box was pervaded by the atmosphere of an affianced couple.
Natásha knew the atmosphere of an affianced couple so well.
Natásha liked the atmosphere of an affianced couple so much.
Natásha turned away.
Natásha suddenly remembered all that had been humiliating in her morning’s visit.
Natásha told herself, "What right has he not to wish to receive me into his family?"
Natásha told herself, "Oh, better not think of it—not till he comes back!"
Natásha began looking at the faces in the stalls.
The faces Natásha looked at were some strange and some familiar.
Dólokhov stood in the front center leaning back against the orchestra rail.
Dólokhov was wearing a Persian dress.
Dólokhov had curly hair brushed up into a huge shock.
Dólokhov stood in full view of the audience.
Dólokhov was well aware that he was attracting everyone’s attention.
Dólokhov was as much at ease as though he were in his own room.
Moscow’s most brilliant young men thronged around Dólokhov.
Dólokhov dominated Moscow’s most brilliant young men.
The count laughed.
The count nudged the blushing Sónya.
The count pointed to Sónya’s former adorer.
The count said, "Do you recognize him?"
The count asked, "And where has he sprung from?" turning to Shinshín.
The count asked, "Didn’t he vanish somewhere?"
Shinshín replied, "He did."
Shinshín said, "He was in the Caucasus and ran away from there."
Shinshín said, "They say he has been acting as minister to some ruling prince in Persia."
Shinshín said, "In Persia, he killed the Shah’s brother."
Shinshín said, "Now all the Moscow ladies are mad about him."
Shinshín said, "It’s ‘Dólokhov the Persian’ that does it."
Shinshín said, "We never hear a word but Dólokhov is mentioned."
Shinshín said, "They swear by him."
Shinshín said, "They offer him to you as they would a dish of choice sterlet."
Shinshín said, "Dólokhov and Anatole Kurágin have turned all our ladies’ heads."
A tall, beautiful woman entered the adjoining box.
The woman had a mass of plaited hair.
The woman had much exposed plump white shoulders and neck.
The woman wore a double string of large pearls around her neck.
The woman rustled her heavy silk dress.
The woman took a long time settling into her place.
Natásha involuntarily gazed at the woman's neck, shoulders, pearls, and coiffure.
Natásha admired the beauty of the woman's shoulders and pearls.
The woman looked round while Natásha was fixing her gaze on her for the second time.
The woman met the count’s eyes.
The woman nodded to the count.
The woman smiled.
The woman was the Countess Bezúkhova.
The Countess Bezúkhova was Pierre’s wife.
The count leaned over and spoke to the Countess Bezúkhova.
The count inquired, "Have you been here long, Countess?"
The count said, "I’ll call, I’ll call to kiss your hand."
The count said, "I’m here on business and have brought my girls with me."
The count said, "They say Semënova acts marvelously."
The count said, "Count Pierre never used to forget us."
The count asked, "Is he here?"
Hélène answered, "Yes, he meant to look in."
Hélène glanced attentively at Natásha.
Count Rostóv resumed his seat.
Count Rostóv whispered to Natásha, "Handsome, isn’t she?"
Natásha answered, "Wonderful!"
Natásha answered, "She’s a woman one could easily fall in love with."
The last chords of the overture were heard.
The conductor tapped with his stick.
Some latecomers took their seats in the stalls.
The curtain rose.
As soon as the curtain rose, everyone in the boxes and stalls became silent.
All the men in the boxes and stalls were old and young and in uniform and evening dress.
All the women in the boxes and stalls had gems on their bare flesh.
Everyone turned their whole attention with eager curiosity to the stage.
Natásha began to look at the stage.
